questions.question_text: Which mechanism must be chosen to optimize the reconvergence time for OSPF at company location 408817202 that is less CPU-intensive than reducing the hello and dead timers?

discussion.content:
A: Is very CPU intesnive as the roiter is stateful switchover due to being broken
B: --> Correct

C: DPD --> Relates to DMVPN or GRE tunnels, and not OSPF specifically
D: OSPF demand circuit is nice as it refreshed LSA's and Hello's based on demand of the peer; this reduces hellos compared to regular OSPF hellos, BUT DOESN"t help in convergeance. In fact if I'm waiting to send out or refresh a hello based on the demand of my peer, this does noting in helping convergeance of a failure.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configured SNMP in R1 to be able to save and upload configurations to the SNMP server but failed when they tried to backup R1 configuration on the server. Which configuration resolves the issue?

comments.content:
They threw us off with A. They didn't mean reliable in the traditional sense. Reliable packets are considered reliable because of an ACK. This is what they meant. BFD in this sense isn't reliable.

According to Cisco Docs BFD is:
Scalable : 1 bfd session can be applied to multiple routing protocols
Replaces Hello Messages: I wouldn't say replace in the traditional sense, but replaces Hello messages for failure detection, when a routing protocol registers with BFD.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
im going with B & D

Replaces hello messages: BFD provides a rapid failure detection mechanism that can be used instead of or in conjunction with traditional hello messages used in routing protocols.

Scalable: BFD is designed to be scalable, allowing it to efficiently detect failures in large networks with minimal overhead.


A is incorrect since reliability is not typically a defining feature of BFD, as BFD's primary goal is fast failure detection rather than ensuring reliability in the conventional sense.

choices.C: It disables label binding information to exchange with peer LSRs.
choices.A: It creates MPLS packet forwarding along with the IGP routes.
choices.D: It enables label binding that exchanges route descriptors.
choices.B: It enables label binding information to exchange with peer LSRs.
